awd_titl_txt: CIF:Medium:Collaborative Research: Foundations of Coding for Modern Distributed Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Coding and information theory provide a very rich body of knowledge from theory to concepts to constructions for creating, leveraging, and removing ?redundancy" in ways that have revolutionized the digital era. This project brings these concepts and techniques to bear in a new field: large-scale distributed computing. The modern paradigm for large-scale distributed computing systems is driven by  "scaling out" of computations across clusters consisting of as many as tens or hundreds of thousands of machines. As such, there is an abundance of resource redundancy that can be exploited. This project develops a foundation for "coded computing", a new framework that combines coding with distributed computing to overcome several fundamental challenges limiting the performance of today's large-scale distributed computing platforms. The research outcomes of the project will be integrated into education and will be disseminated broadly. 

This project takes a principled and foundational approach to providing a unified coding framework to tackle three key challenges in large-scale distributed computing: significant delays due to straggling nodes; large communication loads between computing nodes; and massive input data-sets. In particular, three novel coding concepts are proposed for distributed computing: coding for injecting computation redundancy to mitigate straggler issues; coding to trade local computation with global communication; and coding for statistically principled data sketching. The unified role of codes in both doing fast sketching and in providing robustness to straggler node delays and communication bottlenecks is also studied.

por.por_cntn:
This project took a principled and foundational approach to developing a unified  framework, named Coded Computing, to tackle three key challenges in large-scale distributed computing: significant delays due to straggling nodes; large communication loads between computing nodes; and massive input data-sets.  As a result of this project, Coded Computing, has now turned into an active area of research and development in various fields, including information theory, distributed computing, machine learning, and statistics. This project resulted in various transformative coded computing approaches, namely Polynomial Coded Computing and Lagrange Coded Comptuing, that can be applied to a broad range of computations involving matrix operations and polynomial evaluations. Several of the resulting scientific papers of this project are recognized by best paper awards from IEEE Information Theory Society (Jack K. Wolf Paper Award), IEEE Communication Theory Society (Globecom best paper award), ACM networking community (MobiHoc best paper award finalist), and ACM/IEEE supercomputing society (SC Best paper award finalist). The result of this project were disseminated widely via one workshop, several keynote presentations by PI, and many scientific publications including a monograph on Coded Computing. The project also involved several PhD students and postdoctoral scholars who have now joined the US workforce. In particular, the PhD thesis of the primary PhD student working on this project that focused on development of coded computing, has been the recipient of 2022 Thomas Cover Best Dissertation Award from IEEE Information Theory Society.
